image.altText: A man with a blurred face is led up a path by two other men with blurred faces.

props.synopsis: AFP Commissioner Reece Kershaw and ASIO Director-General Mike Burgess have announced espionage charges against a Brisbane couple. Follow live.

title.children: ADF member and husband accused of attempting to access classified documents for Russia

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Igor Korolev appears in court, doesn't apply for bail
Alleged Russian spies kept to themselves, neighbour says
Russian-born couple identified as Kira and Igor Korolev

image.altText: Burgess and Kershaw stand at a lectern speaking.

props.synopsis: Two Russian-born Australian citizens are accused of obtaining Australian Defence Force material to share with Russian authorities.

title.children: Two Australians charged with spying offences for allegedly conspiring to share ADF secrets with Russia

image.altText: Biden stands at lecturn

props.synopsis: US President Joe Biden is speaking at his first solo press conference in eight months as part of NATO Summit. Follow live.

title.children: Biden says 'there is no indication' of him slowing down after 'Trump' and 'Putin' gaffes

image.altText: A female gymnast puts chalk on her feet.

props.synopsis: An Australian gymnastics coach selected for the Paris Olympics is accused of making comments about a former colleague's breasts and calling her a "minion".

title.children: 'You cannot use that word': Olympic gymnastics coach allegedly made comments about student's body

image.altText: The court logo on the Melbourne Magistrates' Court.

props.synopsis: Michael Stanyer breached consumer law and called debtors "dickheads" and "pathetic lying losers", then told a magistrate he won't be paying his fine.

title.children: Melbourne debt collector fined $15,000 and facing ban tells court 'I'll just keep operating'

image.altText: The couple stand holding a koala

props.synopsis: The family of two Australian victims of a suspected murder at a luxury resort in the Philippines have released a statement saying the situation is "like living a nightmare" and they are "praying for answers".

title.children: Australian couple David Fisk and Lucita Barquin Cortez named as victims in Philippines suspected murder

image.altText: A woman being rescued by a helicopter from the sea in Japan.

props.synopsis: A Chinese woman who was swept out to sea while swimming at a Japanese beach is rescued 37 hours later after drifting in an inflatable swim ring more than 80 kilometres in the Pacific Ocean, officials say.

title.children: 'A miracle': Swimmer swept 80km out to sea in Japan rescued after 37 hours

image.altText: Shelley Duvall with short blonde hair and a fringe smiles at the camera wearing a red shirt

props.synopsis: Shelley Duvall — a regular star in some of the defining movies of the 1970s and 1980s — dies decades after retreating from the spotlight and settling in a small town in Texas.

title.children: Shelley Duvall — star of The Shining and a regular in Robert Altman films — dies aged 75

image.altText: Women in a blue SARG shirt sits with an older looking grey dog

props.synopsis: Animal foster carer Hayley Draper says she is making the most of every day with a dog that was given six months to live.

title.children: Abandoned Daisy defies prognosis after being found riddled with tumours

image.altText: Jen Daine stands under two bridges and looks up into the distrance.

props.synopsis: Commercial photographer Jen Dainer was applying for the Army Reserve when a question about the date of her last period stopped her in her tracks. A Department of Defence spokesperson said the content of the questionnaire is being revised.

title.children: 'I was just shocked to see that question in 2024': Army Reserve applicant withdraws over period question

image.altText: A mother kissing her young son.

props.synopsis: An Adelaide mother who has two months to find somewhere to live with her severely disabled son says she was told to "manifest a home" and use witchcraft or consider living in a tent.

title.children: Public servant advises woman facing homelessness to 'use witchcraft' or 'manifest' home

image.altText: Aerial shot of massive oil and gas rig in the Bass Strait off Victoria

props.synopsis: Offshore gas supplies are running out in the Bass Strait and there are plans to dismantle some of Esso's ocean gas rigs. But the company's intention to leave parts of them in the sea has sparked concerns.

title.children: 'No excuse': Controversy over Esso's plans to dismantle offshore gas rigs

image.altText: Woman wearing an Akubra hat in selfie

props.synopsis: Call for the mandatory return of income support management has some on the edge of tears and fears people could leave towns to avoid the reintroduction.

title.children: 'Don't think we'd survive it': Anxieties that Morrison-era policy could return amid cost-of-living crisis

image.altText: a woman standing in a park with curly hair, smiling, wearing a black jacket and purple scarf

props.synopsis: Elders say it's crucial that positive First Nations stories are shared with non-Indigenous Australians to stamp out racism, and say NAIDOC Week is a chance for those stories to be heard. WARNING: This story contains racist and offensive language.

title.children: Debra and other elders are filled with hope for the future, and say storytelling is crucial

image.altText: Kirsha Kaechele and her fake Picasso.

props.synopsis: The news that supposed Picasso artworks at Tasmania's Museum of Old and New Art were fakes painted by a local artist has drawn a mixed response, with some describing it a damaging to the gallery's credibility — while others have lauded it as a publicity masterstroke.

title.children: 'Brilliant', 'confusing', 'typical Kirsha': Faked Picasso ruse another publicity coup for Mona

image.altText: Richard Marles and Joe Biden shake hands.

props.synopsis: The Australian government is set to give Ukraine another $250 million in military support — its largest contribution to the war effort to date.

title.children: Australia pledges biggest ever boost for Ukraine as NATO calls out China as Russia's 'enabler'

props.synopsis: A look into the transformative journey of Japanese anime from World War II propaganda reels to today's billion-dollar, Pokemon-filled world.

title.children: 'Raised on fantasies': How Japan reinvented itself from military empire to pop culture superpower

image.altText: A wartank on a field with two soldiers on top

props.synopsis: The Israeli army admits it failed to respond appropriately after Palestinian terror group Hamas attacked southern Israel's Be'eri community, killing 1,200 people and taking dozens hostage.

title.children: IDF acknowledges security failings on October 7, including poor response times and disorganisation

image.altText: A row of large white tanks that each read "Cryonics Institute" in a line

props.synopsis: Figuring out how to bring humans back to life is just part of the challenge of cryonics. A reanimated person could also face huge psychological, legal, and financial obstacles in a whole new world.

title.children: Scientists don't know how to stop frozen humans becoming a 'goopy mess', but there are more questions about cryonics

image.altText: There is a large graze on Primoz Roglic's shoulder as he rides his bike

props.synopsis: Primož Roglič loses more than two minutes to his rival Tour de France contenders after crashing near the finish where the new king of sprints, Biniam Girmay, completes a hat trick of stage wins.

title.children: Roglič loses minutes in costly Tour de France crash as Girmay celebrates another sprint stage win

image.altText: Max Purcell and Jordan Thompson during a doubles match at Wimbledon

props.synopsis: Some under-the-radar Aussies are bound for the final while one of the great women's semifinals sets pulses racing on centre court. Here are the five quick hits from day 11 at Wimbledon.

title.children: Five quick hits: Aussies advance to Wimbledon final as marathon women's semi takes players to breaking point

image.altText: A woman holds a mobile phone while waiting to cross the road in Brisbane's CBD.

props.synopsis: If you've got a phone, it's likely you've been on the receiving end of more than a few scam text messages or calls.

title.children: Scammers are using our scam awareness against us

image.altText: ASX 200 board

props.synopsis: Australian shares have set a new record high during trade on Friday after official figures showed inflation has fallen in the US, leading to increased speculation that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates in September. Follow live.

title.children: Australian shares hit new record high after falling US inflation fuels interest rate cut speculation

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Alliance Airlines faces $9 million earnings hit over BHP decision
BHP shares down slightly after Nickel West announcement

image.altText: Satellite image of the sea and a pier.

props.synopsis: The US government says delivering aid to Gazans through the US-built pier was always "intended as a temporary solution", calling for expanded access through land.

title.children: US to permanently close off pier getting aid into Gaza after failed re-anchoring efforts

image.altText: A silhouette of a diver going fishing off NSW coastline

props.synopsis: A court has reversed the burden of proof in a long-running legal battle over cultural fishing rights between First Nations people and the NSW government.

title.children: Legal 'breakthrough' sees roles reversed for First Nations fishers forced to prove connection to country

image.altText: A blue frog on a rock

props.synopsis: A frog hops into a workshop — it sounds like the set-up of a joke, but it is actually the beginning of a startling scientific discovery.

title.children: Out of the blue: Stunningly rare shade of tree frog found on a bench in the Kimberley

image.altText: A wartank on a field with two soldiers on top

props.synopsis: The Israeli army admits it failed to respond appropriately after Palestinian terror group Hamas attacked southern Israel's Be'eri community, killing 1,200 people and taking dozens hostage.

title.children: IDF acknowledges security failings on October 7, including poor response times and disorganisation

image.altText: A woman in a fluro vest stands on a ladder stacking books on shelves.

props.synopsis: Booktopia's collapse has rocked an industry that was already financially on thin ice, so what will fill the giant hole left by its collapse?

title.children: What the collapse of a major book retailer tells us about the state of Australian publishing

image.altText: A black and white dairy cow looks up from its trough of feed

props.synopsis: One of Australia's most expensive environmental policies is changing the way water and land are used to grow our crops and tend to livestock. This is how the Murray-Darling Basin Plan has triggered a mega shift in farmers' thinking.

title.children: Undercover cattle and a boom in thirsty crops — how the Murray-Darling Basin Plan is changing the way we farm

image.altText: made in australia logo

props.synopsis: Senior Labor ministers are accused of "ripping off" an iconic logo used to promote Australian-made products.

title.children: Sussan Ley accuses Labor of 'ripping off' Australia Made logo to promote flagship policy

image.altText: An older man in a suit and red, spotted tie, speaks into a microphone on a podium during an address.

props.synopsis: Labor's Don Farrell is working on changes that would cap both donations and spending during federal elections. But the far-reaching reforms are expected to face a rough parliamentary road ahead.

title.children: Inside the reform battle aiming to protect Australia from 'billionaires who try to influence our elections'

image.altText: A businessman in a red tie raises his hand

props.synopsis: CEO bonuses are becoming a "given" according to a long-running study, despite a rise in investor strikes against remuneration reports.

title.children: The ASX's top earning CEO took home nearly $50m in pay last year, but many execs took a (modest) pay cut

image.altText: A drawing of a mammoth surrounded by tusks and bones

props.synopsis: An incredibly well-preserved woolly mammoth specimen that died 52,000 years ago in Siberia has now had its chromosome structure reassembled for the first time.

title.children: First ancient chromosomes reconstructed from 52,000-year-old woolly mammoth
